column4: Hmm .. Anyone have any advice of setting 1360x768 resolution?
have you tried 'sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg'?
yeah - doesn't add this ood resolution
ive configured xorg.conf with modelines, but the "screen resolution" utility does not reassemble the newly configured xorg when restarted.
have you seen this http://help.ubuntu.com/community/FixVideoResolutionHowto

yeah - used 915resolution instead - no dice. The resolutions I put in xorg.conf isn't added when i restart the system. However if I just do the 915resolution hack and restart X, then I get the 1360x768 fine - when I restart, it's back to default resolutions again (/etc/default/915resolution startup script is configured and an additional script in init.d with the actual hack is also present)
is that init.d script linked from the /etc/rc?.d directories?
alternatively, call the init.d script from /etc/rc.local
Ok - looks like my init.d/widescreen script is executed too late. How would I change the boot priority?
check the links to widescreen in '/etc/rc?.d' and rename them with lower leading numbers
allright...
it's in the rc5.d directory.
do you know what to do?
no, probably not
it's being loaded after gdm... is that a problem?
yes! :)
should I alter all linked rcx.d scripts? (rc2, 3 and 5)
I
I'm not sure, this is dirty-hack territory

heh - well altering the rc5.d only, didn't quite do it - the BIOS hack is applied, but X server hasn't not recognized it - If I shutdown X and start it again - then it works... so the script must be executed too late.
Hmm .. altering all entries didn't work either... any other ideas?
perhaps there is a way to call the script from /etc/init.d/gdm (dirty, dirty hack!)
I'm off now, hope you find a way...
Thank you soo much for the help!!
